trans-unit.source: Composite resources: Using a DSC configuration as a resource
trans-unit.target: Composite resources: Using a DSC configuration as a resource

trans-unit.source: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0
trans-unit.target: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0

trans-unit.source: In real-world situations, configurations can become long and complex, calling many different resources and setting many different properties.
trans-unit.target: In real-world situations, configurations can become long and complex, calling many different resources and setting many different properties.

trans-unit.source: To help address this complexity, you can use a Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) configuration as a resource for other configurations.
trans-unit.target: To help address this complexity, you can use a Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) configuration as a resource for other configurations.

trans-unit.source: We call this a composite resource.
trans-unit.target: We call this a composite resource.

trans-unit.source: A composite resource is a DSC configuration that takes parameters.
trans-unit.target: A composite resource is a DSC configuration that takes parameters.

trans-unit.source: The parameters of the configuration act as the properties of the resource.
trans-unit.target: The parameters of the configuration act as the properties of the resource.

trans-unit.source: The configuration is saved as a file with a **.
trans-unit.target: The configuration is saved as a file with a **.

trans-unit.source: schema.psm1** extension, and takes the place of both the MOF schema and the resource script in a typical DSC resource (for more information about DSC resources, see <linkText>Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration Resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: schema.psm1** extension, and takes the place of both the MOF schema and the resource script in a typical DSC resource (for more information about DSC resources, see <linkText>Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration Resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Creating the composite resource
trans-unit.target: Creating the composite resource

trans-unit.source: In our example, we create a configuration that invokes a number of existing resources to configure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: In our example, we create a configuration that invokes a number of existing resources to configure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Instead of specifying the values to be set in configuration blocks, the configuration takes a number of parameters that are then used in the configuration blocks.
trans-unit.target: Instead of specifying the values to be set in configuration blocks, the configuration takes a number of parameters that are then used in the configuration blocks.

trans-unit.source: Saving the configuration as a composite resource
trans-unit.target: Saving the configuration as a composite resource

trans-unit.source: To use the parameterized configuration as a DSC resource, save it in a directory structure like that of any other MOF-based resource, and name it with a .schema.psm1 extension.
trans-unit.target: To use the parameterized configuration as a DSC resource, save it in a directory structure like that of any other MOF-based resource, and name it with a .schema.psm1 extension.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we’ll name the file xVirtualMachine.schema.psm1.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we’ll name the file xVirtualMachine.schema.psm1.

trans-unit.source: You also need to create a manifest named xVirtualMachine.psd1 that contains the following line.
trans-unit.target: You also need to create a manifest named xVirtualMachine.psd1 that contains the following line.

trans-unit.source: Note that this is in addition to MyDscResources.psd1, the module manifest for all resources under the MyDscResources folder.
trans-unit.target: Note that this is in addition to MyDscResources.psd1, the module manifest for all resources under the MyDscResources folder.

trans-unit.source: When you are done, the folder structure should be as follows.
trans-unit.target: When you are done, the folder structure should be as follows.

trans-unit.source: The resource is now discoverable by using the Get-DscResource cmdlet, and its properties are discoverable by either that cmdlet or by using Ctrl+Space auto-complete in the Windows PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: The resource is now discoverable by using the Get-DscResource cmdlet, and its properties are discoverable by either that cmdlet or by using Ctrl+Space auto-complete in the Windows PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Using the composite resource
trans-unit.target: Using the composite resource

trans-unit.source: Next we create a configuration that calls the composite resource.
trans-unit.target: Next we create a configuration that calls the composite resource.

trans-unit.source: This configuration calls the xVirtualMachine resource to create a virtual machine, and then calls the xComputer resource to rename it.
trans-unit.target: This configuration calls the xVirtualMachine resource to create a virtual machine, and then calls the xComputer resource to rename it.
